name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Also, that #Taiwan wasn‚Äôt invited is unconscionable. Taiwan is a high-standards economy & one of our top trading partners. Its inclusion in what amounts to an economic club would have greatly benefited each of the IPEF‚Äôs pillars. Leaving Taiwan out is a needless bow to the #CCP.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: The biggest problem with the IPEF is that the Administration failed to include market access provisions, which is what the region really wants, and which would have given us something to offer in exchange for advancing the interests of American workers and businesses.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: But there are major problems with IPEF. First, the Administration has been working on the IPEF for months now, but today‚Äôs announcement said that members would start ‚Äúdiscussions toward future negotiations.‚Äù In other words, at this point we are just talking about talking.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Therefore, it‚Äôs good to see that in addition to the United States, the IPEF will include Australia, Brunei, India, Indonesia, Japan, Republic of Korea, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam, which collectively make up 40% of global GDP.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: The Indo-Pacific has 60% of global population and will be the top driver of the world‚Äôs economic growth for decades to come. It‚Äôs absolutely critical that the United States shows economic leadership in a region on which our economic future will increasingly depend.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: China is setting the trade rules in the Indo-Pacific to the detriment of American consumers and businesses. The President‚Äôs announcement today of the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework is a welcome step to get us back in the game, but the framework leaves much to be desired.

tweet_text: With Wednesday‚Äôs decision from the NCAA to suspend its amateurism rules and allow college athletes to follow state laws regarding name, image and likeness compensation, it‚Äôs more clear than ever that a national approach to #NIL compensation will ultimately be necessary.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: The party also deploys its legions online to silence criticism. When American companies spoke up about #Xinjiang, they were removed from online marketplaces, and brands that spoke up faced online harassment ‚Äì all orchestrated by the propaganda wing of the PRC party-state.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: If you are the #AppleDaily and express independent thoughts, you get cancelled. If you are Dr. Li Wenliang and want to speak about COVID, you get cancelled. ¬†If you are a #Uyghur, you get cancelled. ¬†And so on and so forth.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: In other words, they‚Äôve set up the biggest cancel culture in the world, one in which you virtually (and sometimes literally) disappear if you step out of line.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: The #CCP has an extensive #censorship network that seeks to stamp out criticism of the party and its actions.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: My sixth amendment to the #China bill expresses our support for freedom of expression for everyone across the globe.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Consequently, there is no need for the #CCP to communicate its activities to the people, which means it‚Äôs accountable to no one but itself.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: We see openness as a virtue, because in democratic societies, we derive our strength directly from the people, and they have a right to know what their representatives are doing. Chairman Xi and his cronies derive their strength through division, oppression and manipulation.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: My amendment highlights the fact that in China, there is no freedom of the press. We saw this poignantly in #HongKong last week with the shutdown of #AppleDaily, the last pro-democracy newspaper in the city. And that‚Äôs just one example of the PRC‚Äôs efforts to censor the press.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: My fifth amendment to the #China bill expresses support for #PressFreedom in China and around the globe. As Co-Chair of the Freedom of the Press Caucus, I know that a free and independent press is necessary to help citizens hold their government leaders accountable.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: My fourth amendment to the #China bill would drive cooperation with the British and Australians on export controls, which are critical to countering the PRC.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: My fourth, fifth and sixth amendments to the #China bill were adopted by the Foreign Affairs Committee as part of a package of amendments.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Today the #CCP turns 100. From the cultural revolution, to the Tiananmen Square massacre, the oppression of #HongKong, #Tibet, #Xinjiang & the Falun Gong, and the #COVID19 coverup, their rule is an unbroken chain of atrocities. Justice cannot tolerate 100 more years of such evil.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Our allies and partners need to know that the United States will lead the effort to answer the PRC‚Äôs aggressive actions around the globe, and will support and defend them if they‚Äôre willing to stand up to Beijing.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: My third amendment to the #China bill would require the President to develop a whole-of-government strategy to counter the PRC‚Äôs master plan to emerge as the world‚Äôs dominant economic power, and build a global economy centered on Beijing.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Just offered my second amendment to the #China bill, which would remove a reference to executive agreements (Three Joint Communiques) in the bill, preserving congressional silence on these agreements & ensuring the Taiwan Relations Act remains the guiding law on #Taiwan policy.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: The amendment also includes several additional provisions to help bolster #Taiwan‚Äôs defense and improve relations and trade between our two nations.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: These provisions include language to pay the proper respect to #Taiwan as a sovereign nation, and to reaffirm our opposition to any use of force by the PRC against Taiwan.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Just offered my first amendment to the #China bill, to re-insert pro-Taiwan language that had been approved by the Senate, but was left out of the House bill.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Today, the Foreign Affairs Comm. is considering the Democrats‚Äô bill on China - the EAGLE Act. Because the bill fails to meet its primary objective (standing up to the PRC), I can‚Äôt support it as currently written. But, I‚Äôm offering several amendments to improve the final product.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: My bill, H.R. 8265, would reopen #PPP for eligible new and second-time applicants, set aside $10 billion for community lenders, and $25 billion for businesses with ten or fewer employees.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: I strongly urge my colleagues to restart this program and implement my suggested changes to ensure that the smallest businesses (those with ten or fewer employees) and minority-owned businesses get the help they need.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text:
These workers and their families are in jeopardy through no fault of their own.

Small businesses need our help.
 
Right now, there is over $130 billion dedicated to #PPP.  All it would take is congressional action to get this funding into the hands of small businesses.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: A recent @NFIB survey indicated that 49% of small business owners would need more financial support in the next year & that 22% of borrowers anticipate layoffs in the next 6 months. This is unacceptable.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: According to SBA data, the First Congressional District was one of the top recipients of #PPP funding in Ohio, supporting ~250,000 jobs, more than any other Ohio district.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Despite the glitches in the program‚Äôs rollout, #PPP has successfully helped millions of #SmallBiz across the nation.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text:
#PPP was designed to get aid to our nation‚Äôs small businesses quickly so that they could keep their workers on payroll during the pandemic.
 
The @SBAgov worked quickly, and in the first 14 days of the program, they processed over 14 years‚Äô worth of loans.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: As the Ranking Member of the House Small Business Committee, I worked with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to craft the Paycheck Protection Program in response to #COVID.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text:
NEW: @AEI released a preliminary working paper yesterday on the Paycheck Protection Program.

The researchers found that 87% of loans were less than $150,000, a good indicator that the program truly reached small businesses.

Click below for more info:
https://t.co/WRXqwd4yRt

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: ICYMI: https://t.co/kDzFim1NTA

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: My bill, H.R. 8265, would get them the help they need by setting aside $10 billion for community lenders and $25 billion for businesses with ten or fewer employees.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: That is why I am fighting to restart #PPP and ensure that these small businesses are not left behind.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text:
Unfortunately, some mom and pop shops, especially in minority or underserved areas, had trouble accessing the Paycheck Protection Program.

These small businesses faced structural challenges before COVID-19, and many lacked the necessary relationships with traditional lenders.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: As Congress continues to work in a bipartisan, bicameral manner to support small businesses, I am heartened that we moved quickly to improve this program that has already helped millions of small business owners and their workers.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: I applaud the Senate for quickly passing the Paycheck Protection Program Flexibility Act.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text:
RT @HouseGOP: Next stop for the Paycheck Protection Program Flexibility Act ‚ü∂ President Trump's Desk
 
‚úÖ Makes it easier for small business‚Ä¶

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text:
NEWS: "Ranking Member Chabot Praises Senate Passage of PPP Flexibility Act." 

Read the full statement here: https://t.co/BDXhbFX6nX

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text:
Small businesses across our nation have saved millions of jobs through the Paycheck Protection Program. 
 
The Paycheck Protection Program Flexibility Act ensures this program will continue to work for them.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text:
The Senate just passed H.R. 7010, the Paycheck Protection Program Flexibility Act. 
 
This bill, which passed the House by 417-1, gives small business owners more choice in how they use their PPP loan funds. It now heads to the President‚Äôs desk.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text:
Let‚Äôs do our jobs as Members of this Committee and thoroughly investigate these allegations to get to the bottom of what happened. 

Justice, history and the American people deserve at least that much.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: . @RepJerryNadler we‚Äôve served on this Committee and even as Chairman and Ranking Member alongside each other. If nothing more, I ask that you, at a minimum, take the time to bring fact witnesses to testify about the alleged quid pro quo.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: What Democrats are doing today is a travesty in which they are setting the standard for future Administrations.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: The majority really should hold themselves in contempt for conducting this one-sided biased impeachment investigation, and then attacking the White House for refusing to participate in such a patently unfair process.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text:
You want to talk about an abuse of power?  

What the House Democrats are doing here is a clear case of abusing their office for political gain.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: When Congress disagrees with a particular assertion of executive privilege, the remedy is not impeachment. The remedy is to go to court, and let the third branch of government decide who is correct.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Executive privilege is a time-honored, constitutionally protected right of each and every Administration. And it has been asserted time and time again, by Administration after Administration.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Let me make this clear ‚Äî asserting executive privilege is not, in any way, shape or form, obstruction.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: The second Article of Impeachment is nearly as ridiculous as the first. An obstruction charge requires a concerted effort to interfere with or impede a Congressional investigation.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: https://t.co/xVqcSGOa6O

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: But that effort was abandoned because she knows, most Members of Congress know, and now the American people know, ùê≠ùê°ùêûùê´ùêû ùê¨ùê¢ùê¶ùê©ùê•ùê≤ ùê∞ùêöùê¨ùêß‚Äôùê≠ ùêö ùêúùê´ùê¢ùê¶ùêû ùêúùê®ùê¶ùê¶ùê¢ùê≠ùê≠ùêûùêù ùê°ùêûùê´ùêû.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: I guess we now know why Nancy Pelosi was focus-grouping bribery as a potential charge. Because she was desperately searching for a crime to justify this ùê¨ùê°ùêöùê¶ ùê¢ùê¶ùê©ùêûùêöùêúùê°ùê¶ùêûùêßùê≠.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: .@HouseDemocrats If that‚Äôs the best you‚Äôve got, you wasted a whole lot of time and taxpayer dollars, all because the leftist, Democrat base hates this President.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Let me put it another way ‚Äî the entire argument for impeachment is based on a charge that is not a crime (much less a high crime) and that has NEVER been approved by the House of Representatives in a Presidential Impeachment.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: In the Nixon and Clinton impeachments, abuse of power was a tacked-on charge, far less important in those cases than the actual high crimes charged against both men. Here, it‚Äôs the main thrust of the House Democrats‚Äô entire case.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: There is another significant difference between the abuse of power charges against Nixon and Clinton, and those presented here.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Based on the actual facts of this case (as opposed to the hearsay and innuendo compiled by the Intelligence Committee), it doesn‚Äôt appear that an abuse of power even took place, and there certainly isn‚Äôt enough evidence to support an article of impeachment.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Fourth, despite all the efforts to establish evidence of a quid pro quo by House Democrats, Ukraine did nothing to assure the release of the aid. There was no public announcement of an investigation. In fact, it doesn‚Äôt appear that the investigation was even opened.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Third, Ukraine actually received the aid after the President was satisfied that Ukraine had taken meaningful steps to address corruption. Which, again, is an obligation required by law.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: President Trump was well aware of that fact and quite skeptical of giving Ukraine foreign aid long before the now-infamous July 25 phone call.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Second, it‚Äôs a widely known fact that Ukraine is one of the most corrupt countries on the planet. It‚Äôs why Congress required the Administration to certify that the Ukrainian government had taken steps to clean up corruption before military aid could be provided to the country.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: First, there was no quid pro quo.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: In this case, the evidence provided is even less convincing. In fact, I‚Äôd argue it is ùê∞ùê®ùêûùêüùêÆùê•ùê•ùê≤ ùê¢ùêßùêöùêùùêûùê™ùêÆùêöùê≠ùêû.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: In the interests of fairness, I believed that Bill Clinton had abused the power of his office, but we failed to convince our colleagues. The facts didn‚Äôt satisfy the higher burden of proof, and that particular charge was rejected by the full House.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: What they don‚Äôt mention is that the House of Representatives has NEVER adopted abuse of power as a charge in a Presidential Impeachment.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: In their newly authored memo on constitutional grounds for impeachment, the majority on this Committee goes to great lengths to explain why abuse of power is an impeachable offense, specifically mentioning it was one of the charges against both Richard Nixon and Bill Clinton.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Impeachment is reserved for instances of ‚ÄúTreason, Bribery and other high Crimes and Misdemeanors.‚Äù It‚Äôs not ‚ÄúTreason, Bribery, other high Crimes and Misdemeanors‚Äù OR whatever else Nancy Pelosi and Adam Schiff deem impeachable.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: The Constitution is pretty clear on what constitutes an impeachable offense.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: Here are my remarks from last night's @JudiciaryGOP  markup: https://t.co/yRqwJMRzSS https://t.co/DXNs71PnpF

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text:
This is a sad day in American history, Mr. Chairman. 

The folks in the liberal media might be cheering you on, but I highly doubt that either history, or the American people, will judge you so leniently.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: To satisfy their base‚Äôs extreme hatred of President Trump, House Democrats have taken a blowtorch to House rules, the rule of law, and most frighteningly, to the Bill of Rights.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: If George Orwell had written the script, no one would‚Äôve believed it.  People would say that it‚Äôs ridiculously implausible. And yet here we are.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text:
Tomorrow, this committee will hold a vote to impeach a president, without having heard from a single fact witness, and without allowing the minority party the ability to call any witnesses or present any defense. 

What a travesty of justice!

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: The Chairman of this committee, and the majority have seen fit to abuse this committee‚Äôs rules, and ignore the rights of the minority with impunity.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: At the same time, Republicans on this committee were denied their absolute right to have a minority hearing day, which is guaranteed by this committee‚Äôs own rules.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: On Monday, during our second hearing, w/o any fact witnesses, we had the bizarre situation in which rather than Members questioning witnesses, we had staff questioning staff, & even had a staff witness get up from the witness stand & begin questioning another staff witness.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: On Wednesday, this Committee, the committee actually charged with handling impeachment, held the first of two hearings, in which we heard from EXACTLY ZERO fact witnesses.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: After the farce in the Intelligence Committee, we had dumped in our laps a report, recommending impeachment, with no time to adequately consider or review the materials.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: We are witnessing an inexplicable rush to impeach a President who is disliked, no loathed, by most of my Democratic colleagues, and by their supporters, and as a result of that loathing, they have seen fit to abandon all basic tenets of fairness, due process, and justice.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: We are witnessing, I believe, the most tragic mockery of justice, in the history of this nation.

name: Rep. Steve Chabot
tweet_text: I have to say that the last few weeks have been just about the most incredible, and by that I mean most unbelievable, few weeks in my 23 years of service in this Congress.

‚úÖ Strengthens existing passport fee exemptions for state/locally employed first responders contracted with the US Gov to deploy abroad

‚úÖ Extends exemption to volunteer first responders, who play a critical role on disaster response teams
